articles.title: OBSERVER: The evolution of the EU Space Networks
articles.summary:
OBSERVER: The evolution of the EU Space Networks
enora@ALSOcons…
Thu, 27/11/2025 - 15:32

The EU Space Networks have grown from more than a decade of EU-funded activities which explored how to bring satellite data closer to users. These early efforts evolved into the Copernicus Academy and Copernicus Relays, which would eventually grow to more than 300 members worldwide. Their success in supporting Copernicus user uptake inspired the European Commission to extend this model to the other components of the EU Space Programme, creating today’s EU Space Networks and a new generation of Ambassadors for Copernicus, Galileo and EGNOS, Space Situational Awareness (SSA), as well as the upcoming IRIS². These networks now promote EU Space activities and initiatives, help different communities discover and use space-based data and services, support space research and innovation, and engage with policymakers. In this Observer, we look at how these networks emerged and the ways they continue to strengthen skills, foster innovation, and connect users across the full range of EU Space activities. 
 
User uptake initiatives for Copernicus go back to its predecessor, the Global Monitoring for Environment and Security (GMES) initiative, which required an ecosystem of users who understood Earth Observation (EO) data and could integrate it into research, policy, and economic activities. Early activities funded under the EU’s Seventh Framework Programme (FP7) recognised that wide adoption of EO data would depend on more than just launching satellites. It would require local knowledge, training opportunities, and sustained engagement with public authorities, universities, and small businesses.
Two precursor projects played particularly important roles. The first, GMES and  Regions Awareness Access Link (GRAAL), focused on strengthening awareness amongst local and regional authorities and showing institutions how GMES services could support their work. It connected civil servants, early adopters, and emerging user communities, emphasising the need for a regional presence alongside tailored support.
The second, DORIS_NET (Downstream Observatory organised by Regions active in Space), strengthened regional involvement through a network of Regional Contact Offices. It helped public authorities and service providers navigate GMES downstream services, connected regional demand with emerging applications, and demonstrated how systematic regional engagement could support wider user uptake.
These early initiatives revealed that an organised, human-centred approach was necessary for EO data and services to be used to its full potential.
 
Building the Copernicus Academy and Copernicus Relays
Work carried out within GRAAL helped shape the early idea of formal networks dedicated to awareness training and user uptake. The success of GRAAL led to the creation of the Copernicus Academy, formally launched in 2012 through the Salzburg Declaration, which was a joint statement by academic and research organisations supporting closer collaboration on GMES-related education and training. The Salzburg University Department of Geoinformatics, Z_GIS, played an important role in shaping the early vision of a global network, connecting universities, research centres, and training institutions.


September 14, 2012. Photos from the signing of the Salzburg Declaration on GMES-related research, the origin of the Copernicus Academy. Credit: Z_GIS.

 
The Copernicus Academy was created with the aim of facilitating the exchange of best practices across scientific disciplines and national borders. It also aimed to shorten the time it takes for advances in research to result in real-life applications, helping researchers adapt their research results for operational use. Finally, it supported the development of Copernicus-oriented curricula to train the next generation of Earth Observation professionals.
A second key innovation was the creation of the Copernicus Relays, based on the Regional Contact Office concept developed under DORIS_NET, in which organisations served as accessible contact points for Copernicus at regional and local levels. These relays acted as a “local phone number” for Copernicus, providing guidance to SMEs, public authorities, and citizen groups. Together, the Academy and Relays created a more direct link between Copernicus and its users, enabling training, outreach, and local uptake activities to develop in parallel.
 
Institutionalisation: the 2016 user uptake strategy and formal launch
The momentum generated by the GRAAL and DORIS_Net projects resulted in the development of the 2016 Copernicus User Uptake Strategy, in which the European Commission formally committed to supporting the emerging Copernicus Academy and Relays. The Copernicus Support Office (CSO) was created and tasked with coordinating network activities, building communities of practice, and strengthening collaboration between academic, private, and public-sector actors.
This institutionalisation also took place alongside broader initiatives. EO4GEO and the Space Skills Alliance helped define competence frameworks and training pathways and contributed to the wider skills landscape in which the Academy and Relays operated. During this period, institutions within the networks contributed to the development of new higher-education programmes, including an Erasmus Mundus Joint Master’s programme, the Copernicus Master in Digital Earth, led by the University of Salzburg with partner universities in France (Brittany) and the Czech Republic (Olomouc), and another similar programme coordinated by the University of Basilicata, Italy.
 
Demonstrated impact: a growing global community
By the time they reached maturity, the Copernicus Academy and Relays had enlisted more than 300 members in nearly 60 countries. The networks actively contributed to capacity-building efforts, local events, and discussions on national and regional EO strategies. They built bridges between researchers and companies and entrepreneurs, supported public administrations seeking to modernise their data practices, and created opportunities for students to develop the skills needed in an evolving space economy.


The Copernicus Academy and the Copernicus Relays developed a global community connecting universities, research centres, and regional actors to strengthen Copernicus skills, training, and user uptake.

 
Building on the success of the Copernicus Academy and Copernicus Relays, the European Commission expanded this approach to the full EU Space Programme through the creation of the EU Space Networks. These Networks now include member roles for Copernicus, Galileo and EGNOS, SSA–STM, and IRIS².
The EU Space Support Office (EUSSO) is responsible for coordinating, supporting, and animating the EU Space Networks, as well as managing the application and onboarding process for new members.
 
What the EU Space Networks do today and why they matter
Today, the EU Space Networks bring together member organisations which promote the EU Space Programme and its components across different territories and thematic areas. They help raise awareness of EU space data and services, present the Programme at events, and share information with universities, public authorities, businesses, and user communities. They encourage user uptake by informing stakeholders about the availability and benefits of EU space data. Their role in awareness and outreach includes organising or supporting events, webinars, and information campaigns, as well as establishing regional information points which help bring the EU Space Programme closer to potential users. They support community engagement by connecting different actors and sharing best practices related to space applications.


The members of the EU Space Networks have contributed to or participated in a range of projects and initiatives in the space sector, Credit: European Union, Senacyt.

 
In 2024 alone, members of the networks created nearly 300 sets of educational materials and university curricula, participated in over 1,000 and organised nearly 600 events, reaching more than 40,000 people across Europe and beyond. Alongside these broader impacts, members of the networks have contributed to or participated in a range of other projects and initiatives in the space sector. Members of the Copernicus Academy (now Copernicus Ambassadors) made up many of the core partners involved in the Framework Partnership Agreement on Copernicus User Uptake project (FPCUP), which supported user uptake activities through more than 220 actions co-funded by the European Commission and Member States. Members have also played a role in national ecosystem building in their respective countries, for example the Copernicus Academy Consortium in Italy or the national Copernicus Committees in several Latin American countries. Additional activities from members include the organisation or the support to Hackathons, which bring students, developers, and local communities together to experiment with EU space data and applications.
These activities are performed on a voluntary basis and are shaped by the skills and capacities of each member of the networks, reflecting the collaborative spirit on which the networks were built. As Europe prepares for a future shaped by secure connectivity, space safety, and digital transformation, the EU Space Networks will continue to support the visibility and uptake of EU space data and services across diverse communities.
More information about the EU Space Networks is available here.

articles.personality_title: How EU Space Networks grew to connect users with satellite data worldwide
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union has been working for over ten years to help people use satellite data more easily. This started with efforts to teach and connect users of Earth Observation (EO) data through projects like GMES, GRAAL, and DORIS_NET. These efforts showed that satellites alone were not enough; people needed training and local support to make the best use of space data.

**What happened** – Building on early projects, the EU created the Copernicus Academy and Copernicus Relays in 2012. These networks linked universities, research centers, and local organizations to share knowledge and help users apply satellite data in real life. In 2016, the European Commission officially supported these networks and later expanded the model to cover the full EU Space Programme, including Galileo and other initiatives. Today, the EU Space Networks include over 300 members in nearly 60 countries, offering education, outreach, and support to a wide range of users.

**Impact** – The networks have made space data more accessible by creating hundreds of educational materials, organizing thousands of events, and involving tens of thousands of people. They help small businesses, public authorities, students, and researchers learn how to use space data for tasks like environmental monitoring, security, and innovation. This human-centered approach has built a global community that strengthens skills and encourages new ideas across many countries.

**What's next step** – The EU Space Networks will keep growing and supporting users as Europe moves towards new challenges like secure connectivity and space safety. They will continue to organize events, develop training, and help communities discover the benefits of space data. This ongoing work aims to keep linking people and ideas to make the most of the EU’s space investments.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU Space Networks have grown from local projects into a global community that connects people and organizations to better use satellite data for education, innovation, and practical solutions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment les réseaux spatiaux de l’UE ont connecté les utilisateurs aux données satellitaires dans le monde entier
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne travaille depuis plus de dix ans à faciliter l’utilisation des données satellites. Cela a commencé par des projets visant à former et à connecter les utilisateurs des données d’observation de la Terre, comme GMES, GRAAL et DORIS_NET. Ces projets ont montré que les satellites seuls ne suffisent pas ; il faut aussi de la formation et un soutien local pour bien utiliser ces données.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En s’appuyant sur ces projets, l’UE a créé en 2012 l’Académie Copernicus et les relais Copernicus. Ces réseaux ont réuni universités, centres de recherche et organisations locales pour partager les connaissances et aider les utilisateurs à appliquer les données satellitaires dans la vie réelle. En 2016, la Commission européenne a officiellement soutenu ces réseaux et a étendu ce modèle à l’ensemble du programme spatial de l’UE, incluant Galileo et d’autres initiatives. Aujourd’hui, les réseaux spatiaux de l’UE comptent plus de 300 membres dans près de 60 pays, offrant éducation, sensibilisation et soutien à de nombreux utilisateurs.

**Impact** – Ces réseaux ont rendu les données spatiales plus accessibles en créant des centaines de supports pédagogiques, en organisant des milliers d’événements et en impliquant des dizaines de milliers de personnes. Ils aident les petites entreprises, les autorités publiques, les étudiants et les chercheurs à apprendre à utiliser les données spatiales pour la surveillance environnementale, la sécurité et l’innovation. Cette approche centrée sur les personnes a construit une communauté mondiale qui renforce les compétences et encourage de nouvelles idées dans de nombreux pays.

**Prochaine étape** – Les réseaux spatiaux de l’UE vont continuer à se développer et à soutenir les utilisateurs alors que l’Europe fait face à de nouveaux défis comme la connectivité sécurisée et la sécurité spatiale. Ils poursuivront l’organisation d’événements, le développement de formations et l’aide aux communautés pour découvrir les avantages des données spatiales. Ce travail continu vise à relier toujours plus les personnes et les idées pour optimiser les investissements spatiaux de l’UE.

**En une phrase** – Les réseaux spatiaux de l’UE sont passés de projets locaux à une communauté mondiale qui connecte les gens et les organisations pour mieux utiliser les données satellitaires à des fins éducatives, innovantes et pratiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo las redes espaciales de la UE conectaron a usuarios con datos satelitales en todo el mundo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea ha trabajado durante más de diez años para facilitar el uso de datos satelitales. Esto comenzó con proyectos para enseñar y conectar a los usuarios de datos de Observación de la Tierra, como GMES, GRAAL y DORIS_NET. Estos proyectos demostraron que solo los satélites no bastan; se necesita formación y apoyo local para aprovechar mejor estos datos.

**Qué pasó** – Basándose en estos proyectos, la UE creó en 2012 la Academia Copernicus y los Relés Copernicus. Estas redes unieron universidades, centros de investigación y organizaciones locales para compartir conocimientos y ayudar a los usuarios a aplicar los datos satelitales en la vida real. En 2016, la Comisión Europea apoyó oficialmente estas redes y luego amplió el modelo para cubrir todo el Programa Espacial de la UE, incluyendo Galileo y otras iniciativas. Hoy, las Redes Espaciales de la UE cuentan con más de 300 miembros en casi 60 países, ofreciendo educación, divulgación y apoyo a una amplia variedad de usuarios.

**Impacto** – Las redes han hecho los datos espaciales más accesibles creando cientos de materiales educativos, organizando miles de eventos e involucrando a decenas de miles de personas. Ayudan a pequeñas empresas, autoridades públicas, estudiantes e investigadores a aprender a usar datos espaciales para monitoreo ambiental, seguridad e innovación. Este enfoque centrado en las personas ha creado una comunidad global que fortalece habilidades y fomenta nuevas ideas en muchos países.

**Próximo paso** – Las Redes Espaciales de la UE seguirán creciendo y apoyando a los usuarios mientras Europa enfrenta nuevos retos como la conectividad segura y la seguridad espacial. Continuarán organizando eventos, desarrollando formación y ayudando a las comunidades a descubrir los beneficios de los datos espaciales. Este trabajo continuo busca seguir conectando personas e ideas para aprovechar al máximo las inversiones espaciales de la UE.

**Frase clave** – Las Redes Espaciales de la UE han pasado de proyectos locales a una comunidad global que conecta personas y organizaciones para usar mejor los datos satelitales con fines educativos, innovadores y prácticos.

articles.title: Three European astronauts will participate in NASA’s missions to the Moon
articles.summary: Three European astronauts, including one French, will participate in the upcoming missions of NASA's Artemis program, which aims to return to the Moon and establish a sustainable presence there, the European Space Agency (ESA) announced on Thursday.
articles.content:
Three European astronauts, including one French, will participate in the upcoming missions of NASA’s Artemis program, which aims to return to the Moon and establish a sustainable presence there, the European Space Agency (ESA) announced on Thursday.

Bremen (Germany) – “I have decided that the first Europeans to participate in lunar missions will be German, French, and Italian astronauts,” said ESA Director General Josef Aschbacher on the sidelines of the agency’s council in Bremen.

“The first flight will be assigned to a German astronaut,” he added.

The ESA is participating in the American program through the construction of the Orion capsule and is providing elements for the station that will orbit the Moon.

Among the potential French astronauts is Thomas Pesquet, who was present in Bremen and has received support from the minister dedicated to space, Philippe Baptiste.

“This means that Europe has its place in this adventure for the long term, and that France secures its place within Europe,” said Pesquet, who at 47 is the most experienced European astronaut with nearly 400 days in space.

2026 could be the year of the return of astronauts around the Moon, while the Artemis III mission, which will be the first to land them on the lunar surface since 1972, is scheduled for 2027 or 2028. (November 27, 2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant international collaboration in space exploration with European astronauts participating in NASA's Artemis lunar missions, aiming to establish a sustainable presence on the Moon. This represents a meaningful advancement in space exploration with broad public interest and clear details about the astronauts involved and mission timelines.
articles.personality_title: Three European astronauts to join NASA’s missions to the Moon
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA’s Artemis program plans to send astronauts back to the Moon and build a lasting base there. The European Space Agency (ESA) is working with NASA to make this happen.

**What happened** – ESA announced that three European astronauts from Germany, France, and Italy will take part in upcoming Artemis missions. The first flight will include a German astronaut. Thomas Pesquet, a French astronaut with a lot of space experience, is one of the candidates. ESA helps by building parts of the Orion space capsule and the Moon orbiting station.

**Impact** – This is the first time Europeans will join NASA’s Moon missions, marking a big step in international teamwork in space. It shows that Europe has an important role in exploring the Moon, not just the U.S. This cooperation could help everyone learn more about living and working on the Moon.

**What’s next step** – The Artemis missions aim to send astronauts around the Moon by 2026, with a landing planned by 2027 or 2028. The European astronauts will prepare for these missions, and ESA will continue building the spacecraft and station parts.

**One-sentence takeaway** – European astronauts will join NASA’s Artemis missions, marking a new chapter of cooperation to explore and live on the Moon together.
articles.personality_title_fr: Trois astronautes européens participeront aux missions lunaires de la NASA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le programme Artemis de la NASA prévoit de renvoyer des astronautes sur la Lune et d’y construire une base durable. L’Agence spatiale européenne (ESA) collabore avec la NASA pour réaliser ce projet.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’ESA a annoncé que trois astronautes européens, d’Allemagne, de France et d’Italie, participeront aux prochaines missions Artemis. Le premier vol comprendra un astronaute allemand. Thomas Pesquet, astronaute français très expérimenté, fait partie des candidats. L’ESA construit des parties de la capsule Orion et de la station qui orbitera autour de la Lune.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que des Européens participeront aux missions lunaires de la NASA, ce qui marque un grand pas pour la coopération internationale dans l’espace. Cela montre que l’Europe joue un rôle important dans l’exploration de la Lune, aux côtés des États-Unis. Cette collaboration aidera à mieux comprendre comment vivre et travailler sur la Lune.

**Prochaine étape** – Les missions Artemis prévoient d’envoyer des astronautes autour de la Lune dès 2026, avec un atterrissage prévu en 2027 ou 2028. Les astronautes européens se prépareront pour ces missions, tandis que l’ESA continuera à construire les vaisseaux et la station.

**Phrase clé** – Des astronautes européens participeront aux missions Artemis de la NASA, ouvrant un nouveau chapitre de coopération pour explorer et habiter la Lune ensemble.
articles.personality_title_es: Tres astronautas europeos participarán en las misiones lunares de la NASA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El programa Artemis de la NASA planea enviar astronautas de regreso a la Luna y construir una base permanente allí. La Agencia Espacial Europea (ESA) colabora con la NASA para lograrlo.

**Qué pasó** – La ESA anunció que tres astronautas europeos de Alemania, Francia e Italia participarán en las próximas misiones Artemis. El primer vuelo incluirá a un astronauta alemán. Thomas Pesquet, un astronauta francés con mucha experiencia, es uno de los candidatos. La ESA ayuda construyendo partes de la cápsula Orion y de la estación que orbitara la Luna.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que europeos se unen a las misiones lunares de la NASA, lo que representa un gran paso en la cooperación internacional en el espacio. Muestra que Europa tiene un papel importante en la exploración lunar junto con Estados Unidos. Esta cooperación ayudará a aprender cómo vivir y trabajar en la Luna.

**Próximo paso** – Las misiones Artemis planean enviar astronautas alrededor de la Luna en 2026, con un aterrizaje previsto para 2027 o 2028. Los astronautas europeos se prepararán para estas misiones y la ESA continuará construyendo las partes de la nave y la estación.

**Frase clave** – Astronautas europeos se unirán a las misiones Artemis de la NASA, marcando un nuevo capítulo de cooperación para explorar y vivir juntos en la Luna.
